Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 03:50PM sschmidt wrote: Oh my gosh....I can relate.  My first CT showed something on my lung and pelvis and they...the onc or reader...didn't say a word.  later when I got a copy of my records the onc nurse said "what are you doing looking at those?"  "it is probably nothing."  No big deal to her but a really big deal to me.  I had another CT about 1 year later and both spots were gone.  My question is ...where they mets to begin with that were removed by chemo?  Who knows.  My hunch is...sage 1 no nodes is probably, most likely, not mets.  If I were betting on it, I would bet the spots are not mets.. Good Luck to you, Shirley
Posts.Title: Bone Scans and Cat Scans still-me sschmidt

Posts.Content: sschmidt wrote: I have noticed a pinkish spot on the skin under my arm on the tail of the breast for a long time...radiated in October of 06.  Yesterday I noticed that the spot is kind of square...no kidding....straight edges on top and sides.  It is kind of the shape of the opening that the full breast radiation opening looked like.  The radiation techs changed the shape for every patient....like a lead plate with an opening over the beam area. Is this radiation recall?  I don't even know what that is.  Has any of you noticed a pinkish area that stays in the same place for years? I have never thought to bring this up with my Onc.  I also have sore ribs that I am sure is from radiation. Thank you  Shirley Dx 2/10/2006, IDC, <1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 2/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2010 09:36AM sschmidt wrote: I am so sorry Perverson that you have had this hard time with diagnosis.  I too went in thinking stage one and came out being told differently.  After 3 surgeries it was settled.  I felt my world was falling apart and ...it did not.  It was hard, yes, but here I am 4 years later and all is back to a very normal.  I must still be effected or I would not be on this site.  I think about cancer often, but not in that fearful paralyzing way.   You will make it through.  It will be tough but not impossible.  Hang in there with treatment and the sun will shine again.  The most important part is getting treatment.  Science has brought us a long way.   My hunch is you will take the anti-estrogen hormones after you are clean from chemo. I went to a Bernie Segal workshop once, in Northern Cal, and he asked the audience if anyone thought life was not fair.  Everyone raised their hand and he said "that proves it is fair."  It sucks for all of us once in a while.  Sometimes more sometimes less.  Like I said...the sun will shine again. Shirley

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2007 12:39PM sschmidt wrote: I had one of the tumer markers elevated during chemo. I talked to my doctor about that and he said that he wrote a paper about this, 15 years ago, and that through his research the elevated tumer marker meant a higher survival rate. Now that could be just a bunch of bull but it made me feel better.
